This is a complex issue and opinions on non-Maori people getting traditional ta moko tattoos as a form of cultural appreciation versus cultural appropriation can vary within the Maori community.

Traditionally, ta moko has been reserved for Maori individuals who have earned the right to wear certain designs based on their family and tribal affiliations, as well as their personal achievements. It has deep cultural and spiritual significance and is considered a sacred and highly respected practice within Maori culture.

In recent years, some Maori tattoo artists have chosen to offer ta moko to non-Maori customers. However, others feel that certain designs should be reserved for Maori people only, and that non-Maori individuals who get these tattoos may be appropriating Maori culture without fully understanding or respecting its significance.

Ultimately, the decision of whether or not to get a ta moko tattoo as a non-Maori person should be made with careful consideration, respect, and cultural sensitivity. It is important to seek out a Maori tattoo artist and approach the process with humility, recognizing the deep cultural significance of this practice for the Maori people.

It is also important to note that getting a ta moko tattoo as a non-Maori person does not make one an expert on Maori culture, and it is crucial to continue to learn and educate oneself on the complexities of Maori culture, history, and traditions.
